title: Tajikistan - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: Property destruction: On 4 November 2020, policemen opened gunfire in Khorugh city of Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region of Tajikistan and damaged civilians' cars. The reasons for the gunfire were unknown. According to the media, no casualties occurred.
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

On 25 October 2020, around 30 Kyrgyz frontier soldiers approached and opened fire toward Tajik citizens in Isfara, while they were working on water pipes in the disputed territory. No injuries were reported.
SDPT: Social Democratic Party of Tajikistan

On 22 September 2020, two unknown people attacked the leader of the opposition Social Democratic Party of Tajikistan (SDPT) near his home in Dushanbe. According to the SDPT leader, he passed out for four-five minutes, and after he regained consciousness, the attackers were gone.

On 29 August 2020, dozens of workers of the central market in the southern district of Shaartuz (Khatlon) protested against the distribution of space in the new market, which caught fire three months ago and was reopened after renovations. The protestors said the distribution of their place in the market was incorrect and demanded the full restoration of their place in the new market. [size=dozens]

Around 12 August 2020, an unknown number of protesters demonstrated in the town of Vanj of vanj district in Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region against the local authorities forcing beard shaving campaign in the district. [size=no report]

On 12 August 2020, dozens of protesters, including citizens of Russia, demonstrated outside the Russian embassy in Dushanbe city demanding the Russian government organize a charter flight to evacuate its citizens and migrant workers from Tajikistan to Russia. Protesters complained they are stuck in Tajikistan due to coronavirus lockdown in both countries. [size=dozens]

On 6 August 2020, a resident of the village of Samonien in Isfara region of Tajikistan was shot dead a kilometer from the disputed Tajik-Kyrgyz border in the region. Attackers unknown. The incident came on the same day where a Kyrgyz villager and border guard were injured by unidentified attackers, possibly from Tajik side.

On 1 August 2020, about 20 victims of a housing scheme gathered on Rudaki street in Dushanbe city to demand help from the government. The protesters claimed that they have been paying to a residential construction project, but the court canceled their contracts and left them without apartments. [size=about 20]

Around 31 July 2020, a 22-year-old conscript serviceman was pronounced dead after sustaining gunshot wound at the military base 87740 near Bokhtar township in Khatlon region of Tajikistan. The Military first claimed that the soldier shot himself by mistake but then arrested 4 servicemen from the same facility in connection with deadly shooting incident.

On 16 June 2020, people gathered in front of the local administration in Rushan town of Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous region, demanding authorities to solve the case relating to deteetion of three people from the region, over charges of drug trafficking. The detentions took place on May 22 and sparked several demonstrations earlier. [size=no report]

On 1 June 2020, dozens of people have gathered in front of the administration of Rushan district of the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region to deliver their concerns regarding the arrest of the four local citizens, who have escaped and are currently missing and searched by the Tajik authorities. People consider these arrests unlawful. [size=dozens]

On 29 May 2020, residents of the Rushan district of the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region started a protest near the local department of the State Committee for National Security in the district center, demanding the release of three people from the region after the the district authorities detained them over charges of drug trafficking. Residents of the district claimed that the detention took place unlawfully and the detainees were young and innocent. While no specific intervention was reported, all roads were blocked between the GBAO districts reportedly to prevent more residents of other areas coming to join protesters. [size=unknown]

On 29 May 2020, three unidentified men attacked and beat the renown Tajik journalist in Bokhtar during his report coverage from the place of the natural disaster, where people still live in tents. This is the second attack on the same journalist in May. According to the report one the men named himself to be the head of the Jamoat (local administration). [size=3]

On 28 May 2020, residents of the Rushan district of the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region started a protest near the local department of the State Committee for National Security in the district center, demanding the release of three people from the region after the the district authorities detained them over charges of drug trafficking. Residents of the district claimed that the detention took place unlawfully and the detainees were young and innocent. While no specific intervention was reported, all roads were blocked between the GBAO districts reportedly to prevent more residents of other areas coming to join protesters. [size=unknown]

On 27 May 2020, residents of the Rushan district of the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region started a protest near the local department of the State Committee for National Security in the district center, demanding the release of three people from the region after the the district authorities detained them over charges of drug trafficking. Residents of the district claimed that the detention took place unlawfully and the detainees were young and innocent. While no specific intervention was reported, all roads were blocked between the GBAO districts reportedly to prevent more residents of other areas coming to join protesters. [size=unknown]

On 27 May 2020, a Kyrgyz citizen opened fire from Koktash village of Kyrgyzstan and wounded a Tajik woman in Chorku, a Tajik village along the Tajik- Kyrgyz border. According to the border official from both countries, the shooting may have taken place as a provocation as the border violence is going on due to the use of pasture in the undemarcated areas between Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan.

On 26 May 2020, residents of the Rushan district of the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region started a protest near the local department of the State Committee for National Security in the district center, demanding the release of three people from the region after the the district authorities detained them over charges of drug trafficking. Residents of the district claimed that the detention took place unlawfully and the detainees were young and innocent. While no specific intervention was reported, all roads were blocked between the GBAO districts reportedly to prevent more residents of other areas coming to join protesters. [size=unknown]

On 25 May 2020, residents of the Rushan district of the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region started a protest near the local department of the State Committee for National Security in the district center, demanding the release of three people from the region after the the district authorities detained them over charges of drug trafficking. Residents of the district claimed that the detention took place unlawfully and the detainees were young and innocent. While no specific intervention was reported, all roads were blocked between the GBAO districts reportedly to prevent more residents of other areas coming to join protesters. [size=unknown]
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) State Committee for National Security

On 24 May 2020, residents of the Rushan district of the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region started a protest near the local department of the State Committee for National Security in the district center, demanding the release of three people from the region after the the district authorities detained them over charges of drug trafficking. Residents of the district claimed that the detention took place unlawfully and the detainees were young and innocent. The officers shot into the air to disperse the crowd but protest continued. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) State Committee for National Security

On 22 May 2020, residents of the Rushan district of the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region gathered near the local department of the State Committee for National Security (GNKB) in the district center, demanding the release of three people from the region after the the district authorities detained them over charges of drug trafficking. When agents were in the process of moving arrested villagers to the border post nearby, villagers freed 3 detainees using physical force at the GKNB station in town. So far there hasn't been additional reporting with detailed description of how rioters retrieved detainees out of either GKNB vehicle or GKNB station. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Special Purpose Police Unit (OMON)

On 20 May 2020, at least 60 Chinese workers demonstrated at the mining company they worked in Zarnisor, Sughd demanding their unpaid salaries and return to their homes in China over concerns with regard to the spread of coronavirus and alleged absence of adequate medical facilities as well as that Tajik workers are favored over them. Tajikistan's Ministry of Interior claimed that the demonstrators entered the head office with stick and batons upon which OMON Police intervened by shooting into the air and clashing with the workers with bludgeons. Reportedly 45 workers were injured. [size=at least 60]

On 17 May 2020, dozens of residents from Khuroson, Khatlon region protested by blocking the road from Bokhtar to the capital. The crowd critized government's inactivity to recontrust people's houses damaged by torrent earlier in May, demanding immediate involvement. [size=dozens]

On 12 May 2020, two unidentified people wearing face-masks attacked and severely beaten a famous Tajik journalist in Dushanbe. According to the journalist the attack was preceded by numerous threats on a phone, related to journalist's criticism of the Tajik government in preventing coronavirus spread.

On 17 April 2020, the Council of Ul_m_ of the Islamic Center in Tajikistan has banned praying in the mosques for people of Tajikistan for the whole period of Ramadan month, in light of the 'coronavirus' outbreak in the rest of the world.

As reported on 28 January 2020, over the previous week, the arrests of more people that are suspected of membership in Muslim Brotherhood continued in Tajikistan. The number of arrested people has increased from 27 to at least 113. Teachers, governmental employees, writers, students were claimed to be among the detained. The exact locations are not clear but the media reports mention the arrests took place in different locations in the country, with the majority of the detained being in Dushanbe. The report specifically emphasizes the arrests of the relatives of the prominent religious leaders of Tajikistan, who have lately been under the close attention and control of the Tajik government, due to their important role in the Tajik society.
Muslim Group (Tajikistan); Teachers (Tajikistan); Muslim Brotherhood (Tajikistan); Government of Tajikistan (1994-); Students (Tajikistan)

As reported on 20 January 2020, over the previous two weeks a total of 70 people were detained on the suspicion of membership in the Muslim Brotherhood. Teachers, governmental employees, writers, students were reported to be among them. The exact locations of the arrests are unclear, but the media reports mention the arrests took place in different locations across the country, with the majority most likely in Dushanbe.

On 3 January 2020, dozens of residents of Khorugh (Shugnan) gathered in Khorugh demanding the release of the brother of one of the informal leaders of the region after the authorities detained him over the charges of disobeying police officers. [size=dozens]
Muslim Brotherhood (Tajikistan); Muslim Group (Tajikistan); Teachers (Tajikistan); Government of Tajikistan (1994-)

On 2 January 2020 and over the following week, at least 27 people, suspected by the Tajik authorities to be the members of the Muslim Brotherhood were arrested in Dushanbe and in Sughd and Khatlon regions of Tajikistan. According to the report, among the arrested are also the university lecturers and a chairman of a community, a cleric and reportedly a child. Many detained refused being connected to Muslim Brotherhood.

On 31 December 2019, three brothers were detained and tortured by the Tajik Police in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. The counter account has been given by the Ministry of Internal Affairs that asserts one of the detained was arrested on the 30 December while selling illegal narcotics; the Ministry is silent on the account of two other brothers. Meanwhile the mother of the detained insists her son was tortured into confessing the crime.
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service

On 6 November 2019, a group of 20 Islamic state militants attacked Ishqobod frontier post of the Sultonobod unit, in Rudaki region. One police officer and one border soldier were killed. 15 militants, mostly Tajikistan citizens, were killed in the ensuing clashes and five were captured. Some sources claimed seven Tajik soldiers being killed but these reports are unconfirmed. IS militants reportedly entered Tajik border through Afghanistan.

On 28 October, 1622 prisoners were released from Dushanbe prison according to the new amnesty law. Due to the fact that a number of the prisoners were allegedly sentenced to imprisonments because they were affiliated with prominent opposition members, this event may be viewed as strategically important.
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Prison Guards

As reported on 18 October, a criminal case was opened against more than 25 Muslim convicts at a prison in Khujand, Tajikistan, for alleged creation of a Daesh-related cell right in the prison. After the recent large-scale prison riot in Vahdat, the authorities reportedly increased controls in prison facilities.

On 16 October, the parliament of Tajikistan adopted a law on tougher punishment for torture used by law enforcers against civilians. Earlier it was possible to either pay a fine or serve in prison; now the officials are forbidden also to serve for years after their release from prison. The law was adopted after the recent high rise of cases of torture reported in the country.
On 14 October, according to the Press center of the Supreme Court of RT, the National Alliance of Tajikistan was announced by the Supreme Court an 'extremist' and 'terrorist' organization.

On 14 October, the Supreme court of Tajikistan labelled the National Alliance of Tajikistan (NAT), based in the EU [coded to Dushanbe], as a 'terrorist group'. Representatives of the group denied such accusations and claimed that this is only a way how Dushanbe targets the political opposition.

As reported on 11 October, during late September and early October law enforcers organized raids across Tajikistan [coded to Dushanbe], forcibly abducting young men from streets or from their homes and drafting them to the army as conscripts. Their relatives claim that even those who have legal exemption are taken; there were reports of violence used against civilians that defended the young people. The raids were confirmed also by a journalist, who was by chance taken by law enforcers as well, but later released.

As reported on 29 September, law enforcers of the Isfara district, Tajikistan, have been summoning or even detaining residents of the district - parents of young men as a form of pressure in order to make them to join the military forces of Tajikistan. The authorities of Isfara denied the statements and complains, claiming that the residents have been only invited for conversation or explanatory work. [coded according to the version of the civilians]

On 20 September, about 20 residents of Dushanbe gathered for a protest near the building of the administration, complaining against allegedly illegal activities of a local construction company, which - according to them - seized their land and damaged private property. [size=about 20]

On 18 September, delegations of Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan came to an agreement over the border regime, following the recent deadly clash. The discussions were held in the Ovchi kalacha settlement. Negotiators agreed on demolition of a local controversial observation tower, withdrawal of additional military forces and equipment and eventually organization of joint patrols across the border.

On 16 September, a law enforcer reportedly attacked a minor in a school building in Chorku. Due to the recent clashes across the border, law enforcers were present in the area in higher number and one of them allegedly assaulted a student during a lesson for being late for the education. The minor was treated in hospital, the policeman denied the statement. [coded according to the version of the civilian]

On 8 September, a law enforcer was attacked and beaten in Kulob, Tajikistan, while checking a building alongside the planned route of the upcoming Presidential visit to the city. Reportedly he entered a building that belongs to the head of the Tajik governmental communication agency, personally affiliated to the President, who was outraged by the presence of the policeman and attacked him together with his nephews. Later they handed him over to other policemen.
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service

On 3 September, another conflict between Tajik and Kyrgyz local residents emerged across the disputed border area. Reportedly, Kyrgyz nationals illegally entered the Tajik territory in the Chorku district and prevented local Tajiks to return to their homes, because they wanted to establish a market in the area. After arrival of the Tajik border service, they were ousted back to the Kyrgyz territory. Around 20-30 individuals from each side participated in the conflict. [size=around 40-60]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

On 31 August, a clash occurred between local residents of the Chorku district, Tajikistan, and the Kyrgyz border service. Reportedly, the Tajiks started unapproved construction works on a local road, which the Kyrgyz forces opposed, because it runs through a disputed territory. The Tajiks were reportedly resisting the demands and started throwing stones on the law enforcers, but the Kyrgyz servicemen fired several warning shots into the air in self-defense. Later the incident was calmed, and people dispersed. [size=no report]

On 24 August, residents of the Vorukh district in Tajikistan gathered for a rally, expressing their dissatisfaction with a construction of a road through the territory of Kyrgyzstan. The exact number of protesters was not revealed. Later they dispersed. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Prison Guards
In the week of the holiday Qurban (around 9 August), a detained woman in Rudaki village of Vakhsh in Khatlon region was raped by the local police officers.

On 8 August, joint Tajik-Chinese 'anti-terrorism' military exercises were held in Ishkashim, Badakhshan region. The exercises involved motorized divisions, tanks, jets and artillery of the People's Liberation Army of China and the Tajik military. Similar exercises were held in 2016.

On 7 August, a 15yo local resident was brought to the police station in the Varzob district for an interrogation related to a recent murder. Later he stated that he had been beaten and tortured to provide a confession to the crime. His family members reported that the man is partly disabled and incapable of any physical attack and called for an investigation of the case. [coded according to the version of the civilian]

On 4 August, law enforcers of the Vakhsh district reportedly tortured and raped a woman in order to provide confession to an alleged theft. It was reported on 16 September. The Coalition against torture supported the woman, however, law enforcers deny any such accusation. [coded according to the version of the civilian]
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Prison Guards
Eurasianet; Asiaplus; Cabar; Vecherka; Payom; Faraj; NM; Tajikistan Times; RFE/RL

On 7 July, 14 prison inmates were killed in Dushanbe while they were being transferred from Sughd region to prisons in Yovon and Nurek. According to the authorities, they reportedly died due to food poisoning after they had been given three loaves of bad bread during the transfer. However, relatives reported that the bodies had marks of severe beatings, bruises, broken bones, cuts and wounds. Photos on social media soon affirmed this. Some relatives were not allowed to inspect the bodies and had to arrange speedy funerals, while not being allowed to talk to the press - leading many media to suspect torture as a cause of death. Dozens of prisoners have died in Tajikistan under suspicious circumstances before during two prison riots. [coded according to the version of the civilian]

On 1 July, police severely beat and admitted electric shocks to a suspected drug smuggler in Dushanbe until he confessed his crime. Forensic experts later confirmed injuries on his hands and buttocks as a result of electric shocks and beating. [coded according to the civilian's version]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service

On 18 June, another incident related to construction work in the disputed area near settlement Tash-Tumshuk inside the Vorukh enclave occurred. Tajik citizens started construction works, refused to obey commands of the Kyrgyz border service to stop. A conflict among around a 100 inhabitants started and was solved only when Tajik border guards arrived. Reportedly, no one was injured or detained.
On 13 June, journalists of RFE/RL were attacked by bus driver and conductor in Dushanbe during filming videos for a reportage. The bus driver was later fined. [size=no report]

On 10 June, a rally took place in Dushanbe near a building of the EU and the UN. Reportedly, dozens of protesters gathered, demanding the Tajik lawyer working for these organizations not to be released from prison; claiming that he is a criminal and such foreign organization shall not interfere into Tajik internal affairs. [size=dozens]

On 23 May, a skirmish occurred alongside the disputed border between Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan. Reportedly, Kyrgyz residents of Kok-Tash, Aksay district destroyed a fence of a house of a resident of Chorku, Tajikistan, and for several hours also had been blocking a nearby route for Tajik citizens. Around 100 Kyrgyz individuals participated. [size=around 100]
Prisoners (Tajikistan); Islamic State (Tajikistan); IRPT: Islamic Renaissance Party of Tajikistan
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Prison Guards

On 19 May, a violent riot broke out in a maximum-security prison in Vahdat near Dushanbe. Reportedly, 29 inmates and 3 prison guards were killed during the riot, either by other fellow inmates (the IRPT representatives claim that their members were executed by members of ISIS) or law enforcers. Some of the killed inmates were identified as members of the so-called Islamic state and some of the banned Islamic Renaissance Party of Tajikistan (IRPT). Authorities claim the Islamic State group was responsible for stoking the unrest. Immediately following the event, numerous media resources including Google, Youtube and others were again blocked in Tajikistan and unblocked on May 29, right before the arrival of the President of the Council of Europe in Tajikistan. [size=at least 32]

On 29 April, Tajik residents of border area attacked with stones and damaged a car of the governor of Ak-sai village [coded to Vorukh]. The incident occurred several days after another clash of Tajik locals of Vorukh with the Kyrgyz locals from Ak-Sai. [size=no report]

On 29 April, dozens of protesters gathered in Dushanbe near the offices of Faroz company, owned by President's son-in-law, demanding changes in internal economic cut-off of fees and pays. Around 15 protesters were briefly detained. [size=dozens]

On 23 April, the President of Tajikistan announced significant increase of prices for mobile internet, which was followed by an unprecedented public discontent and outrage on social networks; furthermore, a petition was launched against the decision. A group of activists collecting signatures was even briefly arrested (the number is unknown). Reportedly, such perception was not observed at least over the past 20 years [coded to Dushanbe].

On 22 April, violent demonstrations of local Tajik and Kyrgyz villagers occurred in their respective villages in the border area. Reportedly, a young Kyrgyz boy was taken from a settlement Ak-Sai onto the Tajik territory - Tojikon settlement (Isfara district, Vorukh). Although the boy was immediately returned, at least 50 Kyrgyz locals from Ak-Sai spontaneously gathered expressing their anger - blocked a road and vandalized several Tajik vehicles, as well as Tajiks damaged a Kyrgyz one in their area. Three Tajiks were detained. [size=no report]

On 17 April, from 20 to 25 anti-corruption police officers beat a lawyer in Dushanbe in order to make him confess to corruption. The beating resulted in six broken teeth and severe bruises to his face.

On 1 April, residents of Khorug gathered in front of the local police station, demanding release of a man, who was according to law enforcers, an informal head of local criminal gang. [size=no report]
Fergana News; Svoboda ot pytok; RFE/RL; Dialog; NM

On 31 March, two officers detained a drunk man in Dushanbe for urinating in public and beat him in his crotch. He was hospitalized with ruptured testicles and severe damage to his groin, and permanently lost functionality of his sexual organs.
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Prison Guards

As reported on 27 March, inmates of a penal colony in Dushanbe complained of torture and extortion of money. Reportedly the prisoners are frequently beaten or bullied and have to pay to the officers to be treated better. The authorities deny any such accusation, but promised investigation.
On 23 March, a Tajik national was killed by an anti-personnel mine when picking herbs in a hilly area on the border with Afghanistan in the Shohin District of the southern Khatlon Region.
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service
24Kg; TAG News Agency; Eurasianet; The Times of Central Asia; BBC News; RFE/RL; AKIpress; Knews; Sanjar Kalmatai; Ozodagon; Interfax; Nastoyashee Vremya; NM; Intellinews

On 14 March 2019, following the events of 13th March, another conflict broke out in the vicinity of Tajikistan's exclave of Vorukh on the Kyrgyz-Tajik border between local Tajik and Kyrgyz residents. Border forces from both sides intervened. During the collision, the burder guards of Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan and unidentified groups fired into the air. As a result of the conflict, a civilian man died after being struck in the chest by a bullet. Two more Tajik nationals from Vorukh exclave were also wounded. It is not clear if the police shooting into the air caused the fatalities or if the groups had arms. It is unknown if border guards participated in the fighting or tried to brock up it. [size=no report]

On 7 March, traffic police detained a man suspected of car theft in Dushanbe, took him to the police station and beat and kicked him to his head and stomach. He was transferred to another police station and beaten again. Medical examination later revealed he suffered a broken nose, concussion and several bruises to his head.
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service

On 4 January, in Dubeda, Khatlon, Tajikistan [coded to Sary-Chashma], unknown gunmen killed a Tajik border guard on a mission at the Afghan-Tajik border to find a Tajik shepherd who was abducted several days earlier.

In early January 2019, an elderly female resident of Aini district, Sughd region was arrested and reportedly beaten by police officers in order to provide confession to an alleged crime. Later she had to be transferred to a hospital with serious injuries.
IRPT: Islamic Renaissance Party of Tajikistan

On 1 December, the former head of the Tajikistan Banned Islamic Revival Party (IRPT) was detained in Grozny, Chechnya, secretly extradited to Dushanbe and put into a detention facility without any formal arrest; neither a charge to the detainee has yet been filed.

On 1 December, a protest was organized in Khorugh following an accident involving a drunk police officer and a minivan which resulted in the death of two persons. They are asking for the punishment of the law enforcement officer. [size=no report]
Prisoners (Tajikistan); Islamic State (Tajikistan); IRPT: Islamic Renaissance Party of Tajikistan
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Prison Guards
AKIpress; Eurasianet; Nastoyashee Vremya; Ozodagon; Payom

On 7 November, a riot broke out in a high security prison in Khujand. Inmates attacked the prison guards and stole their weapons. 53 people died, including 2 prison guards. Another 186 persons were injured, including 6 prison guards. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the riot. Some sources reported that the riot started after two prisoners were forced to stand in the rain naked. Tajik authorities claim that members of the IRPT were also involved in the organization of the riot, but gave no evidence in support [by default, government claims of IRPT involvement without supporting evidence are not coded]. The head of the facility and his colleagues were arrested and later sentenced for various years in prison for abuse of office. [size=at least 247]
BBC News; AKIpress; Eurasianet; Ozodagon; Vecherka

On 6 November, about a hundred people held an unsanctioned protest in Khorugh against excessive security measures in the region. They demanded the removal of OMON security checkpoints and of additional troops. This occurred a day after two persons were injured by special security forces while protesting. [size=about a hundred]
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) State Committee for National Security
AKIpress; The Times of Central Asia; Nastoyashee Vremya

On 4 November 2018, the State Committee for National Security of Tajikistan arrested 12 Islamic State militants nearby the 201st Russian military base in Dushanbe. They were planning a 'terrorist' attack on the military base because of Russia's involvement in Syria and fight against the IS, as well as the oppression of Muslim groups in Russia.
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Special Purpose Police Unit

On the night between 4 and 5 November, a commander of the OMON riot police fired at protesters with a traumatic pistol in Khorugh who had gathered to demand the removal of a police post established in the center of the city. 2 persons were arrested and 2-3 persons were wounded, which was denied by the police. Authorities claim that the shooting occurred as the result to an attack launched by a powerbroker Khursand Mazorov. [size=no report]
On 18 October, two residents of the village of Kavok located in southern Tajikistan, were killed by an anti-personnel mine explosion near the village.
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Special Purpose Police Unit

In mid-October, in Khorugh, Tajikistan, the authorities deployed elite troops and military roadblocks and warned of a potential military action against several influential local powerbrokers if they would not voluntarily resign their arms and report themselves to the police. The tension was de-escalated through mediation by the newly appointed chairman of the Gorno-Badakshan region Yodgor Faizov, after which the power brokers held meetings with the government in Dushanbe.

On 4 October, a pro-government protest was staged outside the OSCE office in Dushanbe. About 20 young people protested against the presence of the OSCE in Tajikistan accusing it of supporting 'terrorist groups acting against the government of Tajikistan.' [size=about 20]

In mid-September, police forces and military forces were deployed to Khorugh after a visit of the President, and stayed there for several months to combat 'lawlessness,' which raised the tensions with local residents of the region.

On 12 September, a short cross-border altercation erupted between residents of a Tajik and a Kyrgyz village when Tajik residents of the Vorukh exclave started the construction of water pipes. The tension was diffused by negotiations between the mayors of the two opposing villages. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2018, an anti-opposition protest was staged outside the OSCE office in Dushanbe. The protest was organized by the authorities and held at the initiative of the Avangard (Vanguard) group affiliated to the Ministry of Internal Affairs. The demonstrators protested against the participation of the leader of the banned Islamic Revival Party (PIV) and other oppositionists in the OSCE conference. They also held placards reading 'Down with terrorism', 'Down with IRP' and 'We demand that the OSCE office in Dushanbe to be closed' and were also chanting similar slogans. During the protest, the mother of a suspect in the 29 July 2018 deadly attack on foreign tourists in Danghara, poured a liquid over her head and threatened that she would set fire to herself. [size=no report]
AP; AKIpress; DPA; Interfax; Ozodagon; The Times of Central Asia; Trend News Agency

On 26 August, an unidentified armed group [unverified claim by Tajik source it involved the Afghan Taliban] attacked a civilian car at the border of Tajikistan and Afghanistan using Kalashnikovs, light machine guns and mortars. As a result of the attack, two people died and one was injured.
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service
Military Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Border Service
Fergana News; TAG News Agency; Avesta; BBC News; The Right Choice; Asiaplus; AKIpress

On August 17th, 2018, Tajik and Uzbek border guards for the first time in history conducted joint military tactical-special exercises. The main goal of the exercises called 'Jaihun 2018' was to strengthen the border with Afghanistan due to the difficult situation in the neighboring state, as well as to prevent external threats to Tajikistan and Uzbekistan and organize interaction and coherence between border connections in practice.
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service
BBC News; AKIpress; Interfax; TAG News Agency; Kyrgyztoday; Asiaplus

On August 15th, 2018, Tajik border guards temporarily closed the Kokul border checkpoint in Tajikistan's Farkhor District and ceased its operation after the Taliban seized the Aykhanum border checkpoint in Takhar Province of Afghanistan.

The Times of Central Asia; Xinhua; DPA; Sputnik News Service; Tajikistan Times; EuroNews; Trend News Agency; Kyrgyztoday; Gezitter; Avesta; AFP; Bnews (Kazakhstan); AKIpress; Asiaplus; Interfax; AP; Kaktus Media; RFE/RL; The Right Choice

On 29 July, the four foreign cyclists (two Americans, a Dutch and a Swiss citizen) were killed when they were run down by a car along a scenic highway near Safobakhsh, close to Danghara in southern Tajikistan. The attackers plowed into the cyclists with their car, then exited and stabbed the cyclists. Islamic State (IS) claimed responsibility and issued a video on July 31 showing five men pledging allegiance to the group under the organization's black flag and criticizing Tajikistan because it 'has been occupied by infidels.'
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

On 21st July 2018, servicemen of State Border Service of Tajikistan illegally detained two servicemen of the State Border Service of the Kyrgyz Republic and two citizens of the Kyrgyz Republic who were passing through the territory of the settlement of Voruh in Tajikistan. At detention Tajik border guards behaved aggressively and inflicted light bodily injuries to one of the Kyrgyz border guards.
IRPT: Islamic Renaissance Party of Tajikistan

In the summer of 2018, a man was arrested as part of a group of 15 former members of the banned IRPT. Shortly after his release, he committed suicide leaving a video where he declared having been tortured by law enforcements [coded to Khujand].

In July 2018, police detained a man in Yovon district [coded to Yovon] and beat, kicked and gave him electric shocks until he confessed of having committed a stabbing. The victim of the stabbing later stated that the suspect was not the perpetrator and he was released.
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force
Ozodagon; NM; Tajikistan Times; BBC News; Interfax; TAG News Agency

On 8 June 2018, in Buston, the Kyrgyz and Tajik border agencies agreed to ban the use of weapons by their servicemen during conflicts on the common border. The agreement follows a shoot-out between the two countries' border guards on 4 June, when several Tajik servicemen were detained by the other side in a disputed border area. The two countries presented conflicting accounts of the incident, accusing each other of violating the rules of conduct. Border incidents between the two nations are common as they have yet to define about 50 per cent of their 970-km-long common border.

On 21 May, about 50 protesters gathered in front of the embassy of Iran in Dushanbe. They claimed that Iran allegedly supports the banned Islamic Renaissance Party of Tajikistan and demanded stopping it. Police detained several participants and asked them for explanation. According to Eurasianet, the protest was faked by the government. [size=about 50]
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service
Military Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Border Service

On April 25, new Tajik-Uzbek cooperation agreement was revealed and ratified by Tajik authorities. The aim is to prevent further (violent) border disputes: 18 representative offices shall be opened directly on the border in order to resolve any disagreements or disputes directly on the spot.

On 6 April, the local court in Konibodom sentenced three men to prison for theft; then, in protest, their three mothers cut their veins directly in the courtroom, claiming that the law enforcers used torture against the young men in order to obtain confession (unconfirmed). All three received medical treatment later. [size=3]

On 28 March, a resident of Dushanbe was detained by law enforcers and reportedly was tortured by them in order to provide confession to alleged crime possession of drugs. Later he was transferred from custody to hospital in serious condition but died there.

As reported on 20 April, in mid-March a resident of Muminabad was reportedly taken to a local police office and severely beaten by law enforcers, because of his state of intoxication by alcohol. According to his relative, even one month later he still suffered from the consequences of the beating. Exact date of the attack was not specified.
Police Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) State Committee for National Security
On 21 January, a Jehovah's Witness was detained in Khujand and beaten during interrogation by police officers. He was hospitalized with a concussion.

On 9 January, an aggressive crowd of roughly 2500 individuals reportedly gathered in front of the building of the Ministry of Interior Department of Migration issues in Dushanbe. The police forces dispersed the crowd, no detention or major injuries were reported. The demonstrators demanded permission for resettlement to the Russian federation. Tajikistan is well-known for its economic migration to Russia. [size=roughly 2500]
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service
On 7 January, border guards of Tajikistan opened fire at fishermen near Konibodom. One was killed, another wounded. Reportedly the guards opened fire at the fishermen's car, when leaving the area.
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service

On 7 January, Tajik border guards opened fire at a car with five passengers, wounding two and killing one, near the town of Isfara at the border with Kyrgyzstan. The car allegedly disobeyed orders and tried to escape.
